programme.title: Brancaster
programme.desc: The National Trust Roman fort of Branodunum has produced some impressive aerial photographs of cropmarks, promising substantial buildings and multiple finds from the second to the fourth centuries AD.

programme.title: Torre Mayor, Mexico City
programme.desc: The strongest building on Earth, Torre Mayor, is constructed to withstand earthquakes that would obliterate the average skyscraper. Built in the wake of Mexico City’s most devastating earthquake, this building has become a haven in one of the world’s most active seismic zones, but can the ever growing height of skyscrapers compete with typhoons and earthquakes?

programme.title: Eureka Tower, Melbourne
programme.desc: Vertical City goes down under to the tallest residential building in the world: the 300 meter Eureka Tower, the most exclusive address in the Southern Hemisphere. Is living the high life destroying our traditional city communities? Are these Vertical Villages changing the way future generations will live?

programme.title: Commerzbank, Frankfurt
programme.desc: The skyscraper is a symbol of aspiration and power, and an environmentally unsound energy guzzling monster, but in 1997, Norman Foster created a contradiction: the world’s first ecological tower. The Commerzbank in Frankfurt has changed the construction of office buildings forever, but was going green the result of the corporate world being responsible, or just a big fat PR exercise?

programme.title: 7 World Trade Center, New York City
programme.desc: Skyscrapers have transformed cities across the globe, most notably the famous skyline of Manhattan, but on September 11th, 2001, this historic cityscape became forever linked with one event that forced architects to rethink how skyscrapers should be built. 7 World Trade Center, the first building to be constructed on Ground Zero, has taken skyscraper safety innovation to new levels.

programme.title: Turning Torso, Maimo
programme.desc: Every major city has a symbolic piece of architecture that projects its image to the world, but what happens when a city loses not only its trademark industry, but its trademark icon? This is exactly the problem that faced the city of Malmo in Sweden. To recover, they built a radical skyscraper, but daring design always courts controversy. The whole project nearly ended in disaster.

programme.title: Sears Tower, Chicago
programme.desc: Still the tallest tower in the U.S., as well as the tallest building in the world for 25 years, the $175 million Sears Tower broke boundaries in not only height, but design and construction when it was completed in 1973. Building the tallest building in the world brings its own logistical headaches, and the crippling cost of funding an iconic tower can take its toll.

programme.title: The Forgotten Gunners of WWI
programme.desc: The 20th series begins with an examination of what life was like for the First World War Machine Gun Corps, revealing the lost secrets of Belton House, the stately home where they were trained.

programme.title: Barcelona
programme.desc: Symbols of a Barcelona that has once again turned towards its coastline, the twin Vila Olimpica towers hold a treasure. A sea of typically Mediterranean roof terraces, which the Catalonian capital has developed in successive waves. Formerly venues for all types of social encounters, Barcelona's rooftops are gradually regaining their stunning colors.

programme.title: Buenos Aires
programme.desc: Situated within the confines of the pampas region and the river Plata, the capital of Argentina, Buenos Aires, is like a European city in a Latin-American country. Having adopted various cultures from both the Old Continent and Latin America, the city is now home to a giant megalopolis, with flat rooftops, often overwhelmed by heat, which are now a palpable part of daily life.

programme.title: Paris
programme.desc: The shapes, materials, and reflections of Paris's rooftops are what make it so recognizable. They play a crucial role in the city's overall image. These vantages, which offer unforgettable views of one of the world's most beautiful cities and its prestigious monuments, are still often hard to get to. And yet, certain passionate Parisians are gradually adapting these rooftops.

programme.title: Backcountry Traditions S2:E1 "Alaska Part 1"

programme.title: Backcountry Traditions S2:E2 "Alaska Part2"
programme.desc: Alaska is the crown jewel of fisheries. Its undisturbed ecosystem enables the Bristol Bay region to produce and sustain the world's largest sockeye population. The future of this delicate ecosystem is currently threatened by an existential and non-reversible threat. Knowledge is power. Learn how you can join the fight to save and preserve Bristol Bay.

programme.title: The Captain's Log S3:E2 "Blessed"
programme.desc: Capt. Jonathan Moss fishes with Capt. Ulysses Rodriquez for Biscayne Bay Bonefish.

programme.title: Uncharted Waters With Peter Miller S4:E1 "Peter travels to Grande Isle, Louisiana in search of Red Fish and Yellowfin Tuna."
programme.desc: Peter travels to Grande Isle, Louisiana in search of redfish and yellowfin tuna. Fishing the bays and behind shrimp boats. They are treated with a shark frenzy of epic proportions and enough drag pulling action to put the average person in traction…PART 1

programme.title: Uncharted Waters with Peter Miller S4:E2 "Peter travels to Louisiana targeting Yellowfin Tuna and will stop at nothing to find them."
programme.desc: Peter Travels to Louisiana obsessed with the Yellowfin Tuna bite he has heard so much about and won’t stop until sashimi is served. PART 2

programme.title: Uncharted Waters with Peter Miller S4:E3 "Peter and his daughter Emily, target Mahi Mahi, Peacock Bass, Largemouth Bass and Tarpon in Miami."
programme.desc: Peter and his daughter Emily catch Mahi Mahi offshore, Peacock and Largemouth Bass in their backyard and travel to downtown miami to catch Tarpon and are treated to an epic sashimi dinner at Uchi Miami with James Beard award winning chef, Tyson Cole.

programme.title: Midwest Whitetail Offseason S14:E7 "Deadly Setup: The Open Gate"
programme.desc: On this week's episode, we first join Bill as he takes down stands across the farm, inspecting them to make sure they're safe. One of the stands he made his way to was one of the deadliest stands on the entire farm, the "Open Gate." Bill goes into detail on why this stand works so well and relives two successful hunts. Then we join Josh Honeycutt in Kentucky, who gives us an update on how his off-season has been going and introduces his plans to catch up with his top targets this coming fall.

programme.title: Midwest Whitetail Offseason S14:E8 "October Cold Fronts, Kubota RTV X1100C Review"
programme.desc: On this week's episode, we start out by focusing on the early season. We take a look at examples of when it can be great hunting and more importantly, why. Josh Sparks highlights a hunt for a Big 10 he had last October, touching on what he learned and what he would do different, put in the same situation. Next, we join Louie Clouse, on a very similar hunt from 2016, but his hunt ends with a great buck on the ground. Then, we join Bill who introduces the Kubota RTV X1100C he recently was sent to test, discussing why it's such a great option for someone looking to acheive work on their farm. Finally, we join Ben Hampton as he shares his family's favorite venison stroganoff recipe.

programme.title: The "Off-Season" S1:E6 "240 pt. 2"
programme.desc: With a run down and overgrown property that was once for sale, now ours... it's time to get to work. This land is sort of a "blank canvas" with so much potential for my son and I. with the thick bedding cover and an abundance of water sources already present, the sky is the limit once we add food and give the wildlife the security they need... It is now time to turn this 300 acres into a land manager's and die hard hunter's dream!

programme.title: The "Off-Season" S1:E7 "Tree Management"
programme.desc: When people think of creating food sources on their property for deer and other wildlife, the first thing that comes to mind are food plots. While these can produce a high volume of palatable forage, another great option is to plant trees. A variety of soft and hard mass orchards, if cared for properly, can provide another great source of nutrition year round, taking the quality of deer on your property to the next level!

programme.title: The "Off-Season" S1:E8 "Plantation Story"
programme.desc: Every year we try to incorporate new projects to drastically change the quality of habitat we have on the farm for our wildlife. A couple of years ago that project was to create a small hunting plot in the middle of a heavily wooded area in one of our prime hunting locations. This project has turned into what we now call “The Plantation Plot”. As a deer manager creating habitat for the wildlife is one of the most rewarding things you can do. In previous episodes, we went over things like what to do prior to planting, annual vs perennial plots, and even breaking down brand new property. But in this episode we will come full circle, and apply all of those concepts, to create a successful food plot from scratch.

programme.title: The "Off-Season" S1:E9 "Frost Seeding"
programme.desc: Frost Seeding. It's a practice commonly overlooked, but when done correctly can produce major results at a time when wildlife need it the most! And with very little equipment required, this method of establishing food plots is perfect for just about anyone!

programme.title: The "Off-Season" S1:E10 "Trapping"
programme.desc: In the previous episodes of The “Off-Season”, we have talked about creating food sources and building habitat for the wildlife on your property. While these areas of land management are crucial, a successful land manager must also keep their eye on the predator population. Animals such as coyotes, raccoons, and fisher, as well as fox and possums, all prey on either young turkeys or young deer, making it important to control their numbers in order to have the best hunting opportunities.

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: Matt Bergman - A Little Bit Balder Now
programme.desc: Matt Bergman talks about being bad at handhsakes, accidentally breaking into an elderly woman's house, and bombing as an opener for the Goo Goo Dolls with sharp and self-deprecating humor.

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: Joe Zimmerman - Captain Snuggle Pants
programme.desc: Joe Zimmerman grew up in Morgantown, West Virginia, and started his comedy career in North Carolina. While living in the South, his stand-up group the Beards of Comedy landed a record deal with Comedy Central Records.

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: Ricky Glore - Dad Bod
programme.desc: New dad Ricky Glore riffs on wife hacks, dogs dying in horror films, and impersonations of celebrities while reading nursery rhymes

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: Jeff Shaw - Manly Girly Man
programme.desc: Jeff Shaw's writing is marked both by idealism and humanity. His stimulating satire is often infused with poetic beauty. More importantly, he looks like Rod Stewart.

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: Richard Sarvate - Missed the Window
programme.desc: Richard Sarvate quit his ten year programming career in Silicon Valley to be a stand up comedian. Oops! Now he spends his nights poking fun at tech jobs.

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: Reno Collier - Monkeys and Stuff
programme.desc: Reno's journey began at the Punchline Comedy Club in Atlanta, GA where he tended bar to supplement his day job. He found himself on stage during the weekly open mic night. His unique outlook on life - mixed with a six-pack, was instantly popular.

programme.title: Lamont Ferguson - You Had All Day
programme.desc: Ferguson has appeared on the Tonight Show, Comedy Central, Comics Unleashed and ABCís Family Channel. He was the Winner of the Seattle International Comedy Competition, Three time semi-finalist at the Boston Comedy Festival, Finalist in the San Francisco International Comedy Competition and named ëBest of Festî at the Detroit, Lucky Eagle and San Luis Obispo Comedy Festivals. He has the distinction of being one of the only comics in the country that has opened for all of the following comedians: Steve Harvey, George Lopez, Larry Miller, Garry Shandling, Richard Jeni, and George Carlin.

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: Tyler Boeh - Wait For It
programme.desc: Who goes from being a mild-mannered nationally recognized college a Capella group vocal percussionist to becoming a high-energy, intelligent, physical, and downright silly beatboxing comedian? None other than Comedian Tyler Boeh, who shifted his focus from singing a Capella (a word he describes as Latin for “Without Girlfriend”) when he won a comedy contest in Portland Oregon. After winning and placing in the finals of numerous Comedy Competitions from San Francisco to Seattle to Boston to The World Series of Comedy, Boeh not only launched a great career in comedy including television appearances, colleges, cruise ships and headlining clubs, he also found a girlfriend. Tyler’s comedy CD was chosen by LaughSpin Magazine as the Best Comedy Album of 2012 and you may have seen him on such shows as Celebrity Name Game, Moms Rule, Nesn Comedy All Stars, or heard him on SIRIUS radio. Don’t miss a chance to see Tyler live.

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: Maher Matta - Personally Speaking
programme.desc: Born in Lebanon and raised in the American South, Maher Matta jokes about flying while Arab, using Rogaine at fifteen, and working as a state trooper.

programme.title: Dry Bar Comedy: John Branyan - Demeaning of Life
programme.desc: John Branyan's comedy is smart and sarcastic in perfect proportions. This special features his perspective on why God made everyone stupid and his unparalleled Shakespearean take on The Three Little Pigs.

programme.title: Daren Streblow - Organic and Inorganic Life
programme.desc: Daren Streblow’s unique style of observational stand-up comedy has been entertaining hundreds-of-thousands of people throughout the United States and around the world since he first stepped on the stage in 1995. Daren headlines churches, fundraisers, corporate functions, and colleges all over North America. He’s a “humor opportunist” who is always looking for the comical side of life and how people live it. programme.title: We Used to Eat Animals the Right Way - Here's What Changed
programme.desc: Dr. Bill Schindler explains why the processes we have in place today in the food industry lead to a less healthy and enriched lifestyle. The way humans eat animals has shifted. Our brains grew significantly once the human race started hunting its food. Diets that consisted of blood, guts, and organs contributed to that growth. These parts of animals are almost completely absent from modern day diets and these provided much more nutrition than just the animal's meat.

programme.title: What Did We Do Wrong With Dairy Products?
programme.desc: The way that we produce and consume dairy today is nothing like it's been for thousands of years. It has resulted in nutritionally inferior foods. The cows are fed differently, the milk is treated differently and we even eat it differently. The key to unlocking dairy's potential lies in its past. Dr. Bill Schindler talks about dairy fermentation and how modern processes like pasteurization and homogenization can degrade the nutrients naturally present in milk. Find more information on Dr.

programme.desc: This time, we look at our microscopic world. Philippe heads to the University of Texas to break down the microscopic world of sand. He'll stay on campus to then look at how microscopic science plays a role in researching fire ants.

programme.title: Xploration Awesome Planet

programme.title: Hollywood Weapons: Fact or Fiction?

programme.title: Hollywood Weapons: Fact or Fiction?
